p: In this study we compared the growth of an HCV ribavirin resistant mutant (HCV-RR2) to the growth of its parental J6/JFH1 virus in the presence of two antiviral drugs: the mutagenic pyrimidine 5-Fluorouracil and the nucleoside analog 2′-C-Methylcytidine. We show that HCV resistant to ribavirin is more resistant to 5-Fluorouracil but is not more resistant to 2′-C-Methylcytidine ( Figures 1 and 2) than it parental virus J6/JFH1. By passaging HCV-RR2 in 5-Fluorouracil we selected HCV-RR2 resistant to 5-Fluorouracil (HCV-5FU). We confirmed the 5-Fluorouracil resistant phenotype of HCV-5FU viruses by infecting naïve cells and showing that they can grow even in a concentration of 3 µg/ml 5-Fluorouracil ( Figures 3, 4, and 5). HCV-5FU resistant to 5-Fluorouracil acquired synonymous and non-synonymous mutations that were distributed all along the genome ( Table 1).
